text: Hi there, sorry about the (really) late reply, had issues at home. But thank  you for getting back with the informative post. I thought I had scared you with my life-sob story :slightly_smiling_face:

But seriously though, your posts have really opened my mind up. I was curious when i was young(er), but having been stuck in this dead end job for the last 2 years, I sometimes feel that "can I get back into my previous way of thinking". I was always up for something. Now, I have a set routing where I go work, go gym and then spend the evening till late night looking/applying/stressing out over jobs. Though, like you said with distractions, I leave everything behind on the weekends.

I seem to have gotten into this rotten mindset now, where the only thing that keeps me curious is football and video games. but hopefully, my youth will push me through to sort of "rediscover" my old self.

I'm sorry, how rude of me, i didnt ask how you got to where you were and what qualifications you hold now. You seem to have a very interesting story akin to my father who gives me inspiration of "making it"

he moved to this country when he was 5 years old with just his dad leaving the rest of the family back home, went school > college etc but didnt go Uni (not sure if was as accesible back then). He then bounced around jobs all around the country from factory worker to bus driver. It was through the latter that he met someone who mentioned that the council were looking for workers. He then applied and got in, as not many people applied, doing admin. And after a few years of being curious, he managed to bag a role in the accounting department even though he knew jack about working with numbers. From here, they paid to send him to do AAT, as at this point, there weren't many people actuall qualified to do the role. It turned out that my dad was really good at it, excelling in every exam which resulted in him getting a good position. From then on, he continued to grow and so worked in the council for 20+ years, which resulted in him being allowed to retire 3 years ago at the age of 53. In the end, my dad didnt get his big break till he was in his late 20s/early 30s.

So this is sort of my chance to get what will hopefully be my big break a bit more earlier. But looking at my friends who graduated last year, majority of them got a 1st and some have managed to snag a great position. Now, i dont like to be jealous, but it has rejuvenated my competitive spirit to the point where I have to get a position in a career which I have to do well in.

Going back to CIMA and difficulty. How would one cope with the increading pressure of exams and work? At school, I had just the exams, so i had time to mentally prepare myself. during my apprenticeship, we had just coursework, so work itself was never difficult. This feels like it would be a different ball game.
